The current Est for Q2 2013 is 10.24 and that # has been cut from 12.41 90 days ago to 12.17 60 days ago to 10.33 30 days ago to 10.24 this past week. See a trend??? Growth funds do not invest in companies with declining EPS. Even AAPL beats the current Q by 20% (they wont) they are flat with last yr. Where's the growth????

Topic.Title: trading aapl from novice to novice

Message.Msg: The market is a forward looking animal and what it is telling you is that the future earnings at APPL are not going to be good. Competition has caught them. Margins will decline and they will have to sell a ton of more stuff just to keep earnings flat. Growth investors do not invest in companies with flat or declining EPS. This is not the first time this has happened to a company. Just look at Blackberry, a few yrs ago Blackberry was all the rage, where is it today???? Samsung is the new APPL, APPL is the new RIMM/BBRY.

Message.Title: Compare AAPL and BBRY from Sept 19, 2012
Message.Msg: If you went long in AAPL with $100,000 on Sept 19, 2012 and shorted BBRY (then RIMM) with an equal amount, how miserable would you have been? I ask this because that was the prevailing wisdom then. In the same vein, if you had shorted AAPL then and gone long BBRY, how beautiful would your portfolio had been? All the baboons on CNBC (including Cramer and the Fast Money talking heads) had declared RIMM dead and Canaccord was placing an $800 target on AAPL. So much for all the current predictions about the end of BlackBerry. Take my word: AAPL is done. The stock is headed long term to $280, and BBRY is definitely a $50 stock by the end of 2013. I have no apologies for saying this. I have used the BB z10, and it blows everything AAPL has released so far into the gutter. I'm waiting for AAPL to begin launching patent lawsuits all over the place to stop the BBRY momentum.

Topic.Title: Compare AAPL and BBRY from Sept 19, 2012

Message.Msg: I've done a simple math od the whole thing. In the first example you would be losing $122,478 based on the closing prices for Sept 19 and March 1. You would gain an equal amount for the second scenario. Therefore the difference between the two traders in the two examples would be as follows: the AAPL lover will now have only $77, 522 left in his portfolio, while the BBRY realist would have $322,478, a difference of $244,956. I want anyone to dispute these figures. SELL AAPL now. It is still headed downward.

Message.Title: Apple Is Still King Of The Universe
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) has been the subject of dozens of bull and bear thesis articles on Seeking Alpha in recent months. The company went from the most valuable company in the history of this country at $650+ billion to "only" $400 billion today. There is much hysteria regarding how "cheap" Apple is on one side whereas the other says the waterfall decline is warranted. Putting opinions aside, we can use one measure of profitability and management effectiveness to objectively ascertain whether or not Apple's management is getting the most from the company's assets. The metric I will use to demonstrate this point is Economic Value Added. If you are unfamiliar with EVA, the basic premise is that the company's asset base, which is defined as total assets minus current liabilities, gets "taxed" by the company's weighted average cost of capital. After-tax earnings must exceed this "taxed" amount in order to produce positive EVA. If EVA is negative, it means company management isn't producing enough income from the company's asset base to cover its economic cost of financing the assets.

Message.Title: Anyone watch 60 minutes yesterday?
Message.Msg: They interviewed Zhang Zin, China's foremost rock star architect; they talked to her about her rags to riches story, and her net worth is billions; during the interview, she was sitting behind her MACBOOK! She has the pick of any computer, and chooses a MACBOOK; and, if it is like most households, it means she most likely owns an I-Phone, I-Pad or two; and I'd suspect her husband also owns the Mac family of products, and will continue to own Apple products when it comes time for an upgrade. My point is: Years ago, there's no way Mac's would be used by business people; they would own Windows-based products, which would mean it didn't matter what type of phone they owned, and I-Pads didn’t even exist. Apple's IOS-Cloud platform has created an ecosystem that has transformed the computer and phone industry, and will continue well into the future, and can be owned by anyone, even if you're not a billionaire! Of course, one nice thing about people who have more money owning these products is that they are quicker to upgrade, which means more profits for Apple.......and Apple's going broke??? Fat chance!

Message.Title: By Letting The Stock Drop, Tim Cook is Doing the Right Thing
Message.Msg: It sounds counterintuitive, but it's true. He has to do this, as much as it hurts the common shareholder. The more AAPL falls, the cheaper it gets, and the more value per dollar of buyback money the company gets. Buying back at $350 rather than $500 is a huge difference. When those shares get bought back it will only add to EPS in the future. 20 billion dollars at $400/share can get the float down by 50 million shares. This can easily add to EPS by 3-5%. Read the Buffet article when he talks about how Berkshire lost half its value four times in its history. That's when the buybacks were more effective and then the stock came roaring back. I don't believe the hype that AAPL's earnings are crashing or the business is falling apart. No metric out there indicates that is really happening. The only thing that has happened is the stock has lost a mere 35%. It's nothing. The ground can be recovered in less than a year. Look at GOOG in 2009 and 2010. It plummeted but eventually came back. If you are holding for years, then you are in good shape. The near term future may be rough though. Remember the Buffet dictum: don't hold it for five minutes if you aren't willing to hold it for five years.

Message.Title: Feb Note - Innovation Optimism
Message.Msg: The big win is category creation Overall, we think Apple’s intuition to miss some revenue and not dilute its brand is correct. Although some additional iPhone models are needed, in our view, more powerful is creating new product categories and pre-empting competition. CEO Tim Cook continues to emphasize that innovation is alive and well at Apple, and we’re inclined to believe him. Apple’s promise is superior performance at a reasonable price, which cannot be compromised. „ iWatch could be one new category Wearable computing seems a natural evolution for Apple with numerous recent media reports discussing a potential iWatch. A former Apple employee highlights that an iWatch could coordinate other Apple devices and provide new functions, such as eliminating entering passwords, finding your phone, supporting epayments, and enabling apps as another iOS platform. „ Valuation: Buybacks great, but story requires innovation We maintain our Buy rating and $600 price target (based on 10X F13e EV/FCF). We believe product innovation is the best thing that can happen to the stock.

Message.Title: From London FT Times - iPhone 6 and IOS 7 is here
Message.Msg: Jonathan Margolis I’ve often said that our Canadian cousins at BlackBerry have lost the plot these past few years. Well, this, the Z10, suggests they’ve found it again. Within 30 seconds of picking it up, I felt as if I had the iPhone 6 in my hand. Running iOS 7. It is an awesome phone, with a pleasing new operating system, BB10. Both the BlackBerry Z10 hardware and the OS, a Canadian/Swedish/Australian co-production, could have the folks at Cupertino gnashing their teeth, because whatever iPhone upgrade they launch later this year or next, it will surely struggle to catch up. The Z10 looks like the iPhone 5 should have – a bit less tall and thin, a tad chunkier, a bit plastickier, but less chunky than the otherwise lovely (yet doomed) Nokia Lumia 920, which is a crucial 8 per cent wider and over a third heavier than the BlackBerry. It’s not just that the Z10’s physical form resembles a putative iPhone 6; BlackBerry has even designed its app icons to look as I suspect Apple might be redesigning them at this very minute. The Z10 is the fruit of the shake-up following BlackBerry’s dog days in 2011, and its decision to refocus on business users rather than rioters. The problem is that it could continue to appeal to the rioting community – not just because the beloved free BBM messaging system and signature red flashing message light remain, but because the Z10 is superb as a fun machine as well as a business tool. Indeed, it seems BlackBerry has been hoovering up all the clever little developers Apple should have bought. Take a look at the Z10’s analogue-style alarm clock when you play with one – and the genius Time Shift photo mode. Devotees of BlackBerry’s nasty (at least I think) little keyboard and tiny screen may be shocked by the Z10. Its 4.2in touch screen doesn’t even have a physical home button under it, and the phone is operated by single thumb gestures via what the makers call BlackBerry Flow – a rocking system that enables you to keep open multiple ap

Topic.Title: Completely orchestrated collapse in share price

Message.Msg: Monkey, Lord knows I agree with you, but I also think that bluelayersof really did hit a strong note of truth with his/her pithy. "Don't forget that Apple, the company, is facilitating this carnage through secrecy and inaction." The market hates uncertainty, and when you do not give any information and throw investors a lifeline, most people will sell because there is nothing to give them hope or reason. I fail to understand how Tim Cook could take on his attitude. Yes, it's a great company, and yes, they have never bothered about the stock price. However surely as CEO you have SOME duty to choose your words and your presentation very carefully knowing full well that everyone is now looking at some sign. I believe EVERYONE, shorts included, know that AAPL is undervalued. All most people need is some ASSURANCE, some SIGN, some SIGNAL, of something positive from Cook, and they'd be ready to buy in again. The only possibility I could fathom is that either there are no new products coming up, or they don't mind prices dropping so that at very low prices they can do a buyback. More intelligent people than me will doubtless have more explanations, but with regards to Cook's inaction and at times seeming total disregard for shareholder concerns? I am flabbergasted as I am sure many people are.

Message.Title: Watch Could be Worth $6 Billion, Citi Tells Bloomberg
Message.Msg: By Tiernan Ray In case you missed it, Bloomberg‘s Peter Burrows and Olga Kharif this morning write that Apple‘s (AAPL) rumored smart watch could be a big revenue draw for the company, citing comments from Citigroup luxury goods analyst Oliver Chen. Such a device could produce $6 billion in revenue, the analyst says. That, the authors said, would make it more profitable for Apple than a similar share of the $119 billion television market, which might produce just $1.79 billion in annual profit versus $3.6 billion from watches. The authors cite one unnamed source as saying Apple “seeks to introduce the device as soon as this year.”

Message.Title: Apple Hits Jeff Gundlach's Downside Price Target $425
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL) Hits Jeff Gundlach's Downside Price Target March 4, 2013 10:49 AM EST When Apple, Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) was at $500, $600 and even $700 per share one noted bear yelled from the top of the mountain that the stock was a "short of a lifetime." That bear was DoubleLine Capital's Jeff Gundlach. At that time many didn't give credence to Mr. Gundlach's call and chalked it up as just another disgruntled investor that missed the Apple boat. Well, Mr. Gundlach's ship has come in and he is getting the last laugh as today Apple hit his $425 price target. Gundlach has been critical of product innovation at Apple, specially the iPad mini. "When you just change the size of your current product, innovation just isn't there," he said. "What's next a tutti-frutti iPad mini?"

Message.Title: Analyst Estimates Still Coming Down Drastically
Message.Msg: Apple's (AAPL) high growth phase seems to be over. And it was an unusual one, lasting through as much as eight years, which is rare to see. The stock was a leader in many stock market bull cycles, which is also not seen often. The situation we have right now is that it seems the market is anticipating further deterioration of future growth. Hence, the leadership of Apple in the future stock market cycles might be over. The fact is that the growth decelerated significantly, which caused the stock price to drop heavily. Analyst estimates are going down, from $49.28 expected EPS 90 days ago to $44.59 for this year and from $57.95 to $50.51 for 2014. This is normal for stocks when their high growth phase comes to an end. Based on the current valuation and growth expectations, Apple is still very, very cheap, but history shows that what is cheap, might become cheaper. -seekingalpha

Message.Msg: CNBC is all about selling COMMERCIALS! That being said, they get people on there who'll turn heads. THE BIGGEST WAY TO TURN HEADS....BE NEGATIVE! Most people who show their short hands say very conservative statements, nobody makes money investing in convservative investments (at least not good money). How many people remember LIVE AID. At the time was the biggest EVER colaborative effort to raise money and awreness to Africa plyte. IT WILL MOST LIKLEY NEVER HAPPEN EVER AGAIN. It raised over sum $280Million dollars, I bet NO ONE could have guessed this (nuless they look it up). Now ask people who Bernard Madoff was and almost EVERYONE will say he was the guy who LOST BILLIONS! So, sure 280mill is less then 18billion, BUT those 18billion dollars were dollars lost to people for the most part never needed the money under normal living conditions (middle income living is a good normal)...But the BEST EVER HUMANIRTARIAN EFFORT has been long forgotten....why....because it was GOOD NEWS! NO BODY CARES ABOUT GOOD NEWS. Hel the stock market SELLS OFF ON GOOD NEWS, why? Because that's the way it is....DUMDUMDUM...Apple's earnings are strong YES, and LONG TERM it will be a sound investment, but right now, the Neh-sayers are raping this companies valuation. Message.Title: Hereit comes. Real competition Samsung Galaxy S4 Relase date Mar 14
Message.Msg: The Antutu benchmark test reports that the S4 is powered by Samsung's own Exynos 5410 chipset, with its eight cores running at 1.8GHz clock speed. It's coupled with a PowerVR SGX 544 graphics processor, with 2GB of RAM onboard. The S4 in this allegedly current state also feature a 4.99″ display running at 1920×1080 resolution, with Android 4.2 the phone's launch OS. The tested machine featured GSM and LTE radio capability, meaning one version of the device ought to launch worldwide. And there's a 13-Megapixel camera in it. No holes can be picked in those specs. If, of course, these results are genuine—so best keep a grain of salt to hand for now. Samsung to give us all a good look at 2013′s inevitably massively successful phone on March 14.

Message.Title: Buffet Advises Apples New Untested Management To Buy Back Shares
Message.Msg: As Apple shares continue to plummet, Warren Buffet advises to buy back shares Mon, Mar 4, 2013 Apple just can’t seem to do anything right in the eyes of Wall Street these days. Despite record setting profits and tremendous prospects for growth ahead, the company’s share price continues to drop. As of Monday morning, shares of Apple are down $7.04 for the day, trading at $423.49 per share. Overall, this is the lowest shares of Apple have been in well over a year. Early on Monday, famed investor Warren Buffet appeared on CNBC’s Squawk Box where he addressed Apple’s beleaguered share price. “I heard from people each time [Berkshire shares went down], saying why don’t you do this or that. Pay a dividend. I think Apple’s done a good job of building value. They may have too much cash. Now one reason they have so much cash is two thirds of it has not yet been taxed. Further, Buffet said that now may be a good time for Apple to buy back some of its own shares. On that note, Buffet relayed how Steve Jobs once called him up to discuss Apple’s growing cash hoard. “When Steve called me, I said, Is your stock cheap? He said, yes. I said, Do you have more cash than you need? He said, a little. [laughs] I said, then buy back your stock. He didn’t. Now, when our stock went from $90,000 to $40,000 to $45,000, I wrote about, we wanted to buy the stock. We didn’t quite manage to. “But if you could buy dollar bills for 80 cents, it’s a very good thing to do.” Steve Jobs, though, famously ignored Buffet’s advice and reportedly told people that Buffet had privately told him to do nothing with the cash. Oh Steve.

Message.Title: Edward Zabitsky of ACI Research Reiterates Apple SELLTarget $270
Message.Msg: “We got yet another Apple note from Zabitsky on Thursday. Same $270 price target. Same advice to sell the stock short...” “I was right last year. I’ve been right over the last year, that’s all you can say,” Zabitsky told the Epoch Times, saying that his other stock picks are actually doing better. According to Starmine, a service provider for professional investors, Zabitsky was the best industry stock picker for semiconductors and semiconductor equipment over 2012. In his note from last year, as quoted by CNN Money, he cited widely available wireless internet as one of the reasons why Apple would soon run into trouble: “The internet is the great equalizer. It saved Apple during the rise of the wired broadband internet. It will level the playing field for other vendors with the rise of the true mobile broadband internet.” “People realize they can get the internet properties that they want, the key ones [Facebook, YouTube, Google Maps, Netflix, ESPN] they can get these basically anywhere,” he explained in a phone interview on March 1, 2013. “My targets are based upon my expectations for the business over a two year time frame. They are not based upon the current share price,” Zabitsky personally told Elmer-DeWitt last year, according to a CNN post. This illustrates the old investing adage that long-term investing can be very painful. If you have a contrarian call, you often have to wait a long time before the market follows suit. If your analysis is correct, you make money. If your analysis is incorrect, you will have already lost a lot of money before you realize it... As for the future, Mr. Zabitsky thinks that Apple will struggle with the low-end competition of what he calls “good enough” phones. They will be lower quality, but can essentially provide the same internet services for a much lower price. He doesn’t think Samsung will be the spearhead of this move, but rather a host of smaller companies in Asia.

Message.Title: iWatch To Cannibalize iPad And iPhone Apple Likely To Drop One From Product Line
Message.Msg: Will an iOS-Based Apple (AAPL) 'iWatch' Eat Into Other Sales? Apple, Inc. (Nasdaq: AAPL) is hovering near annual lows again Monday as investors are becoming more nervous about the future of the company. According to reports from TheVerge and Bloomberg on Monday, Apple might cannibalize itself via creation of a wristwatch, dubbed the "iWatch." Apple design chief Jony Ive is said to have ordered "boxes" of Nike (NYSE: NKE) sport watches a few years back, Bloomberg noted. The goal was for engineers to take apart and inspect the devices in hopes of evolving the product into something worthy of the Apple name. Instead of using the iPad Nano's touch operating system, engineers are expected to port over a version of iOS to run on the iWatch... Apple may need to release the device before the end of the year as well, with analysts starting to figure a new device into their estimates already... Investors may be hoping for the best, too; many skeptics have surfaced in recent years since the passing of Steve Jobs that innovation has been lost at Apple. Multiple versions of iPhones, iPads, and iPods can only hold attention for so long before another ground-breaking product would be needed. But, should Apple be able to debut a new wristwatch this year and if said watch should run on iOS, the question might now be whether or not consumers will need an iPod, iPad, AND iPhone...or could one be cut out.

Message.Msg: press against them, which comes out hourly, along with all of the reasons for the negativity. If Apple had new products to offer they could confirm this, especially now, and damn their culture of secrecy. If Apple wanted to return some cash back to shareholders, they could have done this yesterday. They know what investors are asking/looking for. If institutional investors and hedge funds believed in what we are hoping for from Apple, they would not be selling Apple every second of every day for 6 months now. Apple doesn't appear to have products coming out that will add to growth 6 months from now. If they did, Apple stock price woulkd not be in free-fall. I now believe that Apple is its own worst enemy. They need new management from outside of the company, not promoted from within like Cook was. Their thought-process over the last 6 months is flawed. Everything changed but they just do not get it. They need a change of leadership.

Message.Title: If things continue as they usually do for AAPL in the afternoon it is not good for longs!
Message.Msg: After 2:00 PM AAPL usually sells of more. I have been going short after 3:00 PM since Valentine's day. Every day but 2 I have made very good money . 1 of those days I was even and I lost a little the other. AAPL is looking weak again today. I am not one that things this stock is a piece of garbage. I am actually waiting for an opportunity to go long because I still think it is a great company. It is just that the big money is playing this company at present on the short side. Today they could decide to cover and go long. I have no idea when they will do that. I watched DE go from 90+ to 20+ in just over 10 months. When DE was 90 I thought it was a great company and at 24 I thought it was a great company. Sure it was worth more than 24 but the big money was making the money on the short side. Wall Street doesn't care about you and I. They take no prisoners. So I have not idea how low they may take AAPL. If we do have a correction in the market it will go much lower in my opinion which means little. Good luck out there and be careful

Message.Title: Control the narrative!
Message.Msg: For as much as Jobs did not manage to the stock price, he managed to the stock price precisely because he controlled the conversation. He owned the public discourse in a powerful, yet usually subtle way. Tim Cook has completely lost control of the narrative. Guys like Jeff Gundlach and David Einhorn dictate the pace. That's unheard of at Apple. The blame begins and ends with Tim Cook. Apple must act. It must act to regain control of the situation. If it's not prepared to do that with new and exciting products, it needs to point the reality distortion field away from itself and back at everybody else ... Now! --Written by Rocco Pendola in Santa Monica, Calif.

Message.Title: Cowen & Co.’s Matthew Hoffman See`s Write Downs On iP5 Over Supplies
Message.Msg: Cowen & Co.’s Matthew Hoffman today reiterates an Outperform rating on shares of Apple (AAPL), while cutting his fiscal 2013 estimates, but raising his fiscal 2014 estimates, on changing time frame for what he speculates will be an “iPhone 5S” later this year. The purported 5S would be equipped with support for China‘s home-grown “TD-SCDMA” 3G network, speculates Hoffman, drawing in part upon work from his colleague, chip analyst Timothy Arcuri. Arcuri thinks that construction of a 5S is trending to June, which is later than the April “ramp” that Hoffman had been modeling. He thinks a phone will arrive in the fiscal fourth quarter of this year, the September-ending period. Hoffman also speculates Apple will have “at least one iPhone model with a 5″ display for late 2013/14,” he writes, which might “shore up the platform”: Smartphone announcements at last week’s Mobile World Congress continue to signal a market shift away from small displays (e.g. LG’s Optimus G Pro display measures 5.5″; ZTE’s Grand Memo has a 5.7″ display). Checks at MWC strongly suggests Apple will add an iPhone variant with a 5+” display. At the same time, Hoffman thinks retailers in Europe are cutting prices to move iPhone units: Our European contacts suggest that channel remains well (over?) supplied with iPhones, though robust promotional activity is now helping to spur demand. What is less clear is exactly how much support Apple is providing for those clearing campaigns. We note demand elasticity for lower-priced Apple smartphones remains high; remember that the $100 or so price cut on the iPhone 4S and 4 drove both SKUs into shortage during F1Q13. Hoffman cut this fiscal year estimate to $182 billion and $44.95 per share in net profit from a prior $188 billion and $46.70.

Message.Title: Here is the reason why I always say technicals are more important than fundamentals
Message.Msg: Here is a cut-and-paste from CNN report. Earlier we noted that with Apple shares falling below $425, it was another feather in the cap for investing god Jeff Gundlach, who predicted last year that Apple would hit this level in 2013. It's important to note what a good call this was. Back at the time the stock was close to $600. We asked Gundlach, via email, whether he had any additional thoughts on Apple's remarkable decline. His short reply is that the decline is a milestone for market theory: AAPL over the last six months offers a textbook case study in market behavior and effectively debunks efficient market theories. The weakness is all the more remarkable because it has occurred within the context of a strong overall US stock market. SPX up 5% since September 19, 2012 and AAPL down 40%. The efficient markets hypothesis basically states the markets are always accurately factoring in all relevant information about a security, and are pricing said security "correctly." From his viewpoint, this proves that markets are not perfectly rational and efficient digesters of news and data, but rather the product of herds and behavioral idiosyncracies, at least somtimes. Apple is a shining example of how it all works.

Topic.Title: Here is the reason why I always say technicals are more important than fundamentals

Message.Msg: If you put Samsung or any other maker into your reasoning items, and ask yourself why should it be a "sure deal" that Samsung/others will/must be doing better than Apple in this market conditions, you will know how "efficiently" and "rationally" the market is. (1) don't have Steve Jobs (2) the market is saturated with iphone, google phone and ms8 phone (3) Apple may push out a check phone (4) now everyone has to face a Ipad and a Ipad mini, no matter which one the customer really wants/prefers (5) everyone is in a 2-year contract with the carriers, few customers left in the market for a smartphone (6) you may get sued frivolously, if you try to follow Apple's design (7) anyone else may continue to develop better products and sell them cheaper (8) iWatch is coming, though it's stupid, but that may be a hit, if you don't have one ...

Topic.Title: Here is the reason why I always say technicals are more important than fundamentals

Message.Msg: Technicals show what the market is actually doing. Fundamentals don't. If A change in fundamentals changes the technicals, it will be reflected in the change of technicals. If it doesn't, it will be reflected in the technicals as well. All I am saying is technicals reflect more than just fundamentals. It also reflects the market psychology and traders emotion. Therefor, trading decisions should be based on technicals and not fundamentals.

Message.Title: I actually feel sorry for the "newbie" longs...
Message.Msg: who continually watch their AAPL investment decline. Many years ago, in my early investing/trading days, I learned the hard way about "falling in love" with a stock, "catching a falling knife", "fighting the tape" (stock-specific or otherwise), and telling myself "just hold on... it will come back". Fortunately for myself, the lesson I learned was only a bruise that I was able to overcome in time. I do feel sorry for the "newbie" longs who are in that "learning" phase and only hope for their sake they learn to recognize their ills sooner rather than later. To the "newbie" longs who have lost a lot in AAPL... do not become discouraged by the losses, use the (learning) experience to your advantage for future investments/trades. All the best to you. Nosmo

Message.Title: Ironic that longs want action from Cook, yet they won't hit the sell button with their own action
Message.Msg: I have been long for four years. Sold my entire stake at an average price of $490 to $500. Wished I sold earlier in the $600's. Cost basis about $190. With that said, while it sucked to sell, I took action and protected profits. It's tiring to here longs talk of "manipulation", "buy the dip this is insane" and "where is Tim Cook?" The fact remains if you want action, take it yourself. Sell. Dont be married to a single stock, ever. The Street is speaking, and it doesnt look good. I challenge any long on the board to tell me why earnings will be good this quarter. I'll give you 50 reasons why they will not. The hardest part for me was to emotionally detach from Apple, the heyday and $700. Dont fall into the same trap I did. If it doesnt feel right, sell it. You can always rebuy

Message.Title: No Buyers and Why?/
Message.Msg: I would suspect that the upcoming earnings report and C.C scaring off anyone and everyone. The company misses here or gives somber guidance and the next stop is well into the 300"s. Why risk that? Especially with so many other miore attractive stories around. You logs doth protest every day ad nauseum. Using one excuse after another - blame this,blame that. The issues and concerns were discussed here all the way down from the high 600"s. You longs were more interested in dissing and taunting. That approach cost you 40% of your equity,if you have any left. And those issues and concerns have come to fruition in several areas. Margin contraction - stiff competition (make sure you continue to deny that) - lack of any new product innovation (and spare us the watch and T.V. nonsense) - management capabilty which is now in question. (you should have sold every share after the Brian William's interview) . Apple is now a commodity company. The mystique is gone.

Message.Title: Why Apple Keeps Falling and Tim Cook's Position
Message.Msg: I would like to explain why Apple keeps falling despite the fact that it is not expensive right now. The price action of its stock is reminiscent of the "forced selling" that is done when a bubble pops. I am not saying that Apple was in a bubble, but that is irrelevant. What happens when a bubble pops is that crazy people who have margined way beyond their means have to get out due to margin calls. What's even worse is that each time they sell, the price goes lower, thus causing even more margin calls not only for themselves but also for others. This domino effect is what causes the price behavior to look irrational. Compounding this effect is the fact that institutions that are value based will not buy Apple until they think they can get it for very cheap, thus the mantra "There is a huge gap between when a growth investor sells and when a value investor buys." With major buyers waiting for the stock to get really cheap, there is no support for the stock, and the forced selling continues unabated. (Note that I do not believe Apple has necessarily become a value stock, but that is the current perception) So what about the company itself? If you look at Tim Cook, you get the idea that he is a tightwad who will drive a hard bargain. He will not want to initiate more buybacks until the stock is "fire sale" cheap. Furthermore, it is my view that he does not care for shareholders: to him they are like parasites that are riding on Apple's success. (He congratulates his employees for their excellent hard work, but calls Einhorn's proposition "A silly sideshow") What he does not understand is that the shareholders are the ones that provide the capital for the company. Although they ride the success, they also suffer the risks and losses in the investment. If he does not care for the shareholders, then why stay public. Take the company private. So what can one do to profit from this situation? Keep buying out of the money weekly put spreads in large quantities.
omg!

Message.Title: Why AAPL will stay cheap
Message.Msg: Many people are overlooking a simple micro trend inside AAPL. As of last quarter AAPL had $7.5 billion in stock repurchase authorization. At a price of $450 (just to make the math easy) they can purchase over 16.5 million shares, compared to purchasing shares at a fair value of $600, or 12.5 million shares. AAPL currently has no incentive to help drive the price higher. AAPL investors should take this in consideration and AAPL traders should also take note. Traders should keep trading and use technical indicators to make as much money as possible. However, if you are an AAPL investor, not a trader who got trapped, keep your shares and the faith. As soon as AAPL has an incentive to raise their share price they will have more then enough weapons to make it happen...P.S. if you are still shorting the stock, please keep shorting the stock, so AAPL can repurchase more shares.

Pure foolishness.Never fight a tape(or sentiment).AAPL was a SELL at $500 on the way up!! The chart turned down LT and only irrational exuberance kept it rising. It ran into the law of large #s. This is NOT a high growth stock anymore. It has to transition to a mature stock and that is painful, especially when they horde their cash. No acquisitive growth like GOOG. GOOG was criticized for YouTube, Double Click and Motorola. Yea,well GOOG folks are smart and noone touches them in search. Jobs' death meant the end of the next great thing too. The last next great thing was the IPad which came out of Steve's head.And the real killer-AAPL has lost its "cool" factor to competition. Check out the phones of teenagers. Not so much AAPL anymore.You're dead wrong IMO, but I wish you the best of luck. Now, when the long GOOG/short AAPL trade ends(it's crowded), AAPL gets a pop probably-a huge bear trap IMO. I'll trim GOOG(again) or just sell it when the TA shows the trade is ending. But, it is GOOG I'll rebuy. I'm done with AAPL-at least for the immediate future(1-2 years IMO).

Message.Title: Don't expect AAPL to get above $500 before the 2nd part of the year
Message.Msg: When AAPL reports in late April do not be surprised if Wall Street continues to slam the company. There is a good chance that they will report another monster quarter, most likely reporting the highest gross income amongst all publicly traded companies. The Street will look at YOY figures and gross margin and say they are signs of concern. And they will be right, sort of, this is because they do not want you to buy the stock while they are buying the stock. Then when the company reports in July they will crush the YOY figures, they will probably have a new product on the market, and the stock will go on a rampage up to the high $500's only to go back down during the fourth quarter. Around this time the company will also double their dividend to 5%. This is when the Street will recommend you buy the stock, becuase they will already be priced in, and therefore they will make a killing.

Message.Title: Made $130K...thanks. I'm done.

Galaxy S4 release on the 14th will be bad for Apple, and earnings are not going to be good either, which always hammer this stock. So if it gets cheap again I'll buy back, but at this point anything over 400 is still expensive given the lack of a catalyst going forward and what the chart says. Tim Cook has proven he is not going to act on investor desires/wants. I don't know how this man will be as a CEO over the next year but he hasn't done much that I have been impressed with. I was hoping to be wrong about my skepticism but I wasn't.

Topic.Title: NEVER IN MY WILDEST DREAMS WOULD I THINK I'D BE DOWN 160K

Message.Msg: Calm down. Apple is no weaker than it was in September, and neither Google nor Samsung are any stronger. The market has turned against Apple because the street got irrationally exuberant, and a lot of investors followed them up - which was a perfect setup for the traders to knock it down as soon as daily volume lagged. You're not the worst investor unless you sell and bake in your losses without a plan. Do you have a good advisor? Speak to him/her, get their help in constructing a balanced portfolio, and whether or not selling AAPL here makes sense for you. AAPL is my largest single stock holding, and yet, as it's been slaughtered, my portfolio value has been stable or very slightly up. I've just bought some more healthcare - I own IHE, and it's done very well, up more than 17% since I bought it less than a year ago, and today bought some XLV, to dilute out my AAPL. Just stay calm. You're not the worst investor.

Topic.Title: 764 shares average at 456.

Message.Msg: Stay cool, this is not a broke company yet. This is not a Sony yet. It sells products that people want, need, and upgrade often. People do not trow out TVs every 2 years, but they do upgrade their cell phone every 2 years. People will revisit this growth story soon. You should get a divided pop (and/or buyback) in the next couple of weeks. You should also start getting interesting numbers from China embedded within an inline Q1 report perhaps reminding people that this is still an aspirational brand in parts of the world. But you will not make a profit until the company shows it can disrupt new markets. iWatch, iTV and who knows what else, it can technically buy Tesla for chump change and really disrupt a huge market icar would send this stock to new highs and even 1000. But from where we are today this requires dreaming. So if u want that Audi now, just sell when you get back your 456.

Topic.Title: Any news pushing this down?...serious replies please

Message.Msg: Perhaps the question is not what is causing it to collapse, but rather what pushed the price where it had no business going? Think the price drop is significant now? Wait till T-Mobile drops their subsidies, with ATT, Verizon, and Sprint all following suite, customers will be paying the full unsubsidized price, what effect on the Apple stock price do you think that will have? With Nokia's new factory coming on line next month, somewhere in the 50 million unit range per quarter, with Nokia pushing out volumes in the low, medium, and high end, at what point will Nokia surpass the number of handsets that Apple is selling on a per quarter basis, what effect do you think will have on the Apple stock price? Unless Apple has some real tricks up their sleeves, just set back and watch Apple continue to head lower to areas of support, consolidate to the point where support becomes resistance, then each leg down will become more and more painful. Even the high today was below the 52 week low, Apple stock is in serious trouble. Feel sorry for those that have not had the discipline to have pulled the trigger and go into cash.

Message.Title: The "never say never" paradigm...
Message.Msg: When AAPL went to a new high of $364 2 years ago and then fell back to an intraday $315, a few swore "AAPL will never see $364 again, ever...". Uh huh. Then when we went over $400 and fell below it bashers said "We'll never see $400 again, ever...". Uh huh. Then when we went last year to $643 intraday and then fell back all the way to $530 bashers said "We'll never see $600 again, let alone $640, ever...". Uh huh. Then when we went to $705 intraday and fell below, bashers said "We'll never see $700 again, ever...". As we have fallen since 20 September all the way down, pumpers have said "We'll never see $nnn again, ever...". Uh huh. So we don't know what's coming. What we do know is that it's apparently not a good idea to say we'll never see that number again. We'll we go back up? I think we will. Will we go down more first? Maybe. Will we ever see $300 or $705 again? Maybe. Will I guarantee it? Never. Is there is money to be made either way in smart trading? Always. Love a company but not a stock.

Message.Title: Short AAPL?
Message.Msg: Buyer of options have been making a few people very rich. So many people think the stock "must" return to higher values soon, that they're still willing to buy options, and the money managers are blue in the face from laughing so hard. But more people start considering shorts, and more people bet on that. As soon as there is an opportunity to extract more money out of the shorts rather than expired options, the price can be driven up. I think it's time for those who want to donate their life savings to MMs, to stop buying options, and start shorting. Your sacrifice will be appreciated. For the rest of us... can it be enough to buy a stock at a price that you're comfortable with, and are willing to hold on to through near-term turmoil and possible long-term trends? Is there any chance that us boring investors can outweigh the many---too many---who are making trades that encourage manipulation?

Message.Title: Why is the Reality of the Issues and Concerns re AAPL
Message.Msg: that have been widely disseminated since September so foreign to the longs. They have numerous reasons and blame game rationales for the decline. Everything is a conspiracy - everybody who dares to discuss and document the concerns is put upon. The stock is dpwn for real reasons. Reasons pertaining to the fundamentals and how those fundamentals apply to the future growth prospects of the company. And how thw Market values those prospects. Clearly,there are many who now question the outlook for the company and the prospects.They have been discussed here in detail and won;t rehash them. But the longs are more interested in trash talk issing those that discuss the issues instead of objectively considering them. If you longs disagree that's fine.But this daily nonsensical ranting and raving against all that you perceived as causing you your losses only identifies your amateurish inexperience. The fact is you caused your losses. You bought the stock (anyone who bought options excluded - they never had much of a chance)to start with)- you should know that stocks have principle risk and that it went against you. It happens. Somehow you felt that loss potential didn't apply with Apple. You know - it's APPLE - God of God,King of Kings. and such. You made your call - you lost. Acceot it,learn from it,move on. Stop blaming everyone else. Grow up,the world is real. It's not some video game.

Topic.Title: Can anyone really doubt?

Message.Msg: So What? Apple's stock price is nearly 20 times higher. At Apple's current stock price, 1 billion of their cash will buy back only a little over 2 million shares. They could spend 25% of their free cash and only get back 10 million shares. There lies your problem. The stock needs to be a lot lower in order for a buy back to have any effect and increasing the dividend uses up cash so that's not going to help. You also need a good dividend yield of 3% or better to entice income investors. So , again the stock price needs to be much lower for income investors. As far a new product announcement, there talking about getting into watches? How about toothbrushes? This just reinforces ithe idea that they're out of ideas.

Topic.Title: Is AAPL really only worth $40?

Message.Msg: Well the company has roughly $140 per share in cash right now. Backing that out from the current stock price leaves about 280 for the 40 billion per year in cash flow. Any beginning business student can tell you that's only 7 times earnings. Google is about 15 times earnings now (after backing out the cash) and CNBC can't stop talking about it. Apple would have to increase about 280 per share to simply match current Google valuations.

Topic.Title: You won't publish curse words but you will publish hate messages

Message.Msg: Yahoo bases their display advertising rates here on impressions. They'll never block a user's IP address as they need max eyeballs to rake their advertisers. So don't count on those who post hate getting banned. In fact, the ONLY reason they started censoring bad language is due to pressure from certain big advertisers such as those who's stories are linked on the summary page of each stock. You don't think those news story links are there because they're helpful....do you? Yahoo is getting paid for that.

Topic.Title: Find It Hard to Believe...

Message.Msg: It is market. The brokers create the demand and supply. If you are their friend, you can bet with them and if you are not their friend they can bet against you. Stories,tales, rumors and Marketing are their weapons along with a 10 day volume. A 10 day volume can rinse the calls and puts a long way until the retail investors or institutional investors get interested in the stock. It started before the earnings. CNBC,news articles. Bear case for AAPL etc. Earnings though good, did not meet the high end of the analyst estimate, If AAPL/TC was smart, he would have anticipated this move and announced a buyback during the call. Now the damage is done more than anticipated. It is like steering a bus without brakes on a downhill/ uphill road. Downhills will be faster and uphills will be tough to hold on to.. The support is broken easily and it will not be far before big funds start to unload if TC does not act to provide a solid base. KKD is an example. It does not matter if the PE is 1 or .01. The company needs to provide support for its broken stock. Fix the breaks.

Message.Msg: You sound rational about it. I'll give you an idea of how to handle it if you still believe in APPLE long-term (as Time Cook said people should). First there may well be more excitement about Apple mid-year when alot of articles say Apple will be introducing new Smartphones. (right now Samsung and Blackberry have intro'd new phones). So the thing to do is buy Call Options on Apple Stock for this Fall. Buy "in the money calls" and you won't pay that high a premium above the current market price of the stock... and yet you'll need a lot less capital to own the potential appreciation, than from owning the shares outrighe. Options are risky though--- its taking a chance.

Message.Title: Logic thinking
Message.Msg: Forget AAPL at $700. AAPL is at $420 now, is AAPL undervalued now? the answer is yes. Can AAPL go even lower? yes. Where is the absolute bottom? no one knows. Is it good enough to buy at current level? Absolutely. The logic plan is: divide the money left into 3 Buy 1 now. if it goes down another 10%, buy another 1; if it goes down 20%($340)(it will not happen if the whole market doesn't crash), buy another 2. Then you are done. Close the book. Check back in one year.

Message.Title: Tomorrow is a huge day for AAPL....and the entire market....HERE IS WHY
Message.Msg: Everyone has forgotten about the impact of the 'sequestration'....the markets were on the sidelines to see what the heck was going to happen....hence a relatively positive reaction by Wall Street on both Friday (03/01/13) and today (03/04/13). Today was a 'tester' for the market....please look at the daily charts and dare me if I am wrong. The markets came up in the last hour today and it will be an up week all week long. Yes, Apple ended up down but it was much due to the month long haircut. This week, the markets will end up significantly (if the US does not decide to do a pre-emptive strike on Iran, which is likely to happen before June 1st)...and AAPL will end up about 460 or 470 by weeks end. Please understand that Apple is still a risk only because of a TON of issues going on right now at the company. The biggest reason? Major investors are physically LAUGHING at the iWatch....they laughed and then sold their shares and then they shorted the shares!!!! There are major reasons to be concerned about Apple but there is a major correction occurring this week to the upside. So hold tight until month end...and then, it is anybody's guess. But by end of March Apple should be at the 525 range.

They would make much more money just 1/ getting a relationship started with China mobile and 2/ making a cheaper more utilitarian phone for developing markets. Maybe take a page out of Nokia's book but don't buy them as I stand to make a lot money riding that pony that Apple. Management here cannot multitask. CEO's job is much more than just creating and selling good products. He employs people do these functions. Jonny Ive has been quiet of late. Is he still with the Company or has he been fired as well. Apple now is like a possessed beast living in tis own world deliberately trying to isolate itself from the business community. almost like it is trying to hide something. Is Jonny Ive still alive? If he goes this ship will really sink. and to think I have been one of the believers since this stock was $12. The magic has left this Company. Nothing inspirational or idealistic about this Company anymore. Like a dog and its master, it has died with Steve. God bless his soul. So long Apple.

Topic.Title: Would you wear an iWatch?

Message.Msg: I sure as hell not going to wear a freak google goggle. Glasses are obstructive and ugly, and uncomfortable. Do you really want to see the weather all the time? Information needs to be ready not constant. No one want constant information. Google glass is SHIT. Think about a glass that interact with your eye. At any moment you are driving, some shit pop up and you just rear end another guy. And where are you going to put that glassed when it made a impression your nose. Contact was created because people don't want to wear glasses. Lasik was created because people don't like even to wear contacts. Now watches people wear them without thinking about them. Imagine something around your wrist that you can make calls. Hell you don't even have to use your hand to make calls, since a watch when making calls use the same motion as your current clunky phone. One less thing in your pocket. And you never lose them. Google Glasses are shit.

Topic.Title: I am finished.

Message.Msg: It wouldn't do you any good to analyze this, but since you are curious about it, I will share my opinion. In a sense Apple corp. had not much to do with stock pricing, when you bought you were under the illusion that apple stock (by itself ) had a justification for such price ($650), when in reality it was wall street who drove the price up by greed (calling it a "growth stock"), apple kind of fell for it and the proof is: they did not split the stock allowing it to go so high and took advantage of the momentum in sales growth due to their phone market and tablet market dominance. Steve Jobs was good at many things and so this stock performed well under him, but not the case Tim Cook, unfortunately he will not do any good. Now, here is what is going on (IMHO), Wall street knows apple won't be the same success story it was before (see proof in the last 3 quarterly reports, don't be fooled by them making money but concentrate on the fact that they showed a slow down). Wall street dislikes Tim Cook, they know were Tim is going, Tim if not dismissed will turn apple in to a company that introduces minimal changes in their products and cater to a niche paying for an overprice item in a saturated market, he will soon attempt to get higher pay as a CEO since Wall Street killed the options trading (see every Friday's closing). In the end it does not matter how much wall street tells you this is a good stock $500 or $800, in reality no stock should be price that high in retail, same goes for Google Inc.
